__NOTOC__{{Infobox military person |name=Heinrich-Hermann von Hülsen |birth_date={{birth date|1895|7|8|df=y}} |death_date={{death date and age|1982|6|6|1895|7|8|df=y}} |birth_place= [[Weimar]], [[Grand Duchy of Saxe-Weimar-Eisenach]], [[German Empire]] |death_place= [[Celle]], [[Lower Saxony]], [[West Germany]] |image= |caption= |nickname= |allegiance={{flag|German Empire}} (to 1918)
{{flag|Weimar Republic}} (to 1920)
{{flag|Nazi Germany}} |branch=[[German Army (Wehrmacht)|Heer]] |serviceyears=1914–47 |rank=[[Generalmajor]] |commands=9th Rifle Brigade
9th Panzer Grenadier Regiment
[[9th Panzer Division (Wehrmacht)|9. Panzer-Division]]
[[21st Panzer Division (Wehrmacht)|21. Panzer-Division]] |unit= |battles=*[[World War I]] ---- *[[World War II]] |awards=[[German Cross]] in Gold |laterwork=}} '''Heinrich-Hermann von Hülsen''' (8 July 1895 – 6 June 1982) was a decorated [[Generalmajor]] in the [[Wehrmacht]] during [[World War II]], who commanded two armoured divisions. Hülsen commanded the 44th Reconnaissance Battalion of [[44th Infantry Division (Wehrmacht)|44th Infantry Division]] into the [[Invasion of Poland]] at the beginning of World War II, and led this unit until 5 December 1939. He then served as [[Adjutant]] in the high command of [[1st Army (Wehrmacht)|1st Army]] until 1 April 1941, and was promoted to [[Oberst]] on 1 December 1940 during this service. On 1 April 1941 he took command of the 2nd Mounted Regiment, which he led into [[Operation Barbarossa]], until he was called back into reserve on 1 December 1941, and was awarded the [[German Cross]] in Gold on 2 November 1941. On 25 May 1942 he took command of the 9th Rifle Brigade under [[9th Panzer Division (Wehrmacht)|9. Panzer-Division]], which he led in the southern theater of the [[Eastern Front (World War II)|Eastern Front]] until 5 July 1942. Taking command of the 9th Panzer Grenadier Regiment until 15 December 1942, he was also named temporary commander of [[9th Panzer Division (Wehrmacht)|9. Panzer-Division]] from 27 July until 3 August 1943 during this service.{{cite book |last1=Glantz |first1=David M. |last2=House| first2=Jonathan| date=2009 |title=To the Gates of Stalingrad: Soviet-German Combat Operations, April-August 1942 |publisher=University Press of Kansas |location=Lawrence, Kansas |page=26 |isbn=9780700616305 }} Called back into reserve on 15 December 1942, he next took command of [[21st Panzer Division (Wehrmacht)|21. Panzer-Division]] on 25 April 1943 in North Africa. After having been promoted to [[Generalmajor]] on 1 May 1943, on 13 May 1943 he was captured by British forces in the area of [[Tunis]], [[Tunisia]], and was in captivity until 17 February 1947. From late summer 1944, von Hülsen was interned in [[Clinton, Mississippi]].{{cite book |last1=Mallett|first1=Derek R.| date=2013 |title=Hitler's Generals in America: Nazi POWs and Allied Military Intelligence |publisher=University Press of Kentucky |pages=77–78 |isbn=9780813142531 }} ==Awards and decorations== * [[Iron Cross]] (1914) * [[Honour Cross of the World War 1914/1918]] * [[Iron Cross]] (1939) * [[German Cross]] in Gold (2 November 1941) ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-mil}} {{succession box| before=Generalleutnant [[Johannes Bäßler]]| after=Generalleutnant [[Walter Scheller]]| title= Commander of [[9th Panzer Division (Wehrmacht)|9. Panzer-Division]]| years=27 July 1942 – 8 August 1942 }} {{succession box| before=Generalleutnant [[Hans-Georg Hildebrandt]]| after=unit surrendered to British forces| title= Commander of [[21st Panzer Division (Wehrmacht)|21. Panzer-Division]]| years=15 March 1943 – 13 May 1942 }} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hulsen, Heinrich-Hermann von}} [[Category:1895 births]] [[Category:1982 deaths]] [[Category:Major generals of the German Army (Wehrmacht)]] [[Category:Recipients of the clasp to the Iron Cross, 1st class]] [[Category:Recipients of the Gold German Cross]] [[Category:Reichswehr personnel]] [[Category:People from Weimar]]
